subject: Entrepreneurship
title: Kiva: Peer-to-Peer Lending Goes Global
description: Learn Kiva: Peer-to-Peer Lending Goes Global in one minute.

hook.text: In 2005, a couple in San Francisco asked: what if anyone could lend $25 to an entrepreneur across the world?

buildup.text: Matt Flannery and Jessica Jackley built Kiva, connecting everyday lenders with borrowers in need globally.

discovery.text: Kiva doesn't give charity. It makes loansâ€”and 96% get repaid, recycling money to the next borrower.

twist.text: Critics found that loans are often pre-funded by local banks before you lend. Your $25 isn't truly direct.

climax.text: Despite the controversy, Kiva has facilitated over $2 billion in loans across 77 countries since launch.

punchline.text: Twenty-five dollars connects strangers across the planet.

quiz.question: What criticism did Kiva face about its peer-to-peer lending model?
options: Borrowers almost never repaid their loans
Loans were often pre-funded by local partner banks before individual lenders contributed
The platform charged extremely high interest rates to borrowers
